title: Protocol for cell-type-specific tissue reconstruction in the murine lung fibrogenic microenvironment
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Sample collection, enzymatic tissue digestion, and mechanical dissociation
Timing: 60 min
This part details how to collect samples, perform enzymatic digestion, and mechanical dissociation.
For the isolation of alveolar epithelial type 2 (AT2) cells,
Anesthetize mice by intraperitoneal injection of pentobarbital (40–50 mg/kg) with 10 U of heparin sodium, and dissect the mice.
Expose the trachea and intubate a 20-gauge catheter into the trachea (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
      Methods video S2. Tracheal exposure and intubation, related to step 1
    
After exposing the trachea, make a small incision to insert the catheter. Secure inserted catheter with sutures.
Open the abdominal cavity, and euthanize mice via transection of the abdominal aorta.
Open the thoracic cavity and perfuse the lungs with 10 mL of cold 0.9% saline from the right ventricle (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2451-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Tissue digestion of murine lungs
(A) Perfusion with saline from the right cardiac ventricle.
(B) Protease mix instillation from the catheter inserted into the trachea.
(C) Low-melting point (LMP) agarose instillation from the catheter.
(D) The ice pack for solidification of LMP agarose.
(E) Murine lungs removed from the thoracic cavity after protease mix instillation.
(F) Lobes are separated from lung minimizing bronchus tissue contamination.
(G) Separation of each lobe after incubation with protease mix.
Note: Cutting the right ventricle just after perfusion prevents the blood from perfusing the lungs again.
Fill the lungs with protease mix.
Instill 1.5 mL of protease mix into the lungs through the intubated catheter (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Instill 0.2 mL of 1% LMP agarose solution through the catheter (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Cover the trachea with ice and wait for 2 min (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).

Note: Instillation of protease mix from the catheter inserted into the trachea facilitates tissue dissociation with a small amount of protease mix.
Remove the lungs from the thoracic cavity (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E). Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Perform enzymatic digestion and mechanical dissociation of the lungs.
Incubate the resected lungs in 2 mL of HBSS at 37°C for 30 min.
Separate each lobe (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F) and transfer them to a gentleMACS C tube containing 5 mL of processing medium (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G).
Dissociate tissues in a gentleMACS C tube with the preset program B_01.
Add 100 μL of DNase I and incubate at 37°C for 3 min.
Critical: Complete perfusion with saline can remove blood from the lungs and improve the sorting efficiency of AT2 cells by FACS.
For the isolation of human lung parenchymal cells or lung cancer cells,
Obtain human lung parenchyma or cancer tissues from patients undergoing lung resection due to lung cancer.
Note: Maintain human lung parenchyma or cancer tissues on ice from sample collection to mince.
Mince lung parenchyma or cancer tissues into small fragments (10–50 mm3) using a pair of sterilized scissors (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2451-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Tissue digestion of human lungs and preparation of single cell suspension
(A) Human lung parenchymal tissues minced into 10–50 mm3 fragments.
(B) Human lung parenchymal tissues before incubation in protease mix.
(C) Transfer of cell suspension through cell strainers.
(D) The cell pellet derived from human lung parenchyma after red blood cell lysis.
Perform enzymatic digestion and mechanical dissociation.
Transfer tissue fragments into 50 mL conical tubes containing 5 mL of protease mix and incubate at 37°C for 1 h (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Transfer digested tissues to a gentleMACS C tube.
Dissociate tissues in a gentleMACS C tube with the preset program B_01.

Add 100 μL of DNase I and incubate at 37°C for 3 min.
Preparing single-cell suspension (common for murine AT2 cells and human lung parenchymal or cancer cells)
Timing: 25 min
This part details how to make the single suspension, which is common for the isolation of murine AT2 cells and human lung parenchymal or cancer cells.
Filter cell suspension through cell strainers (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Place 70 μm and 40 μm cell strainers on 50 mL conical tubes and moisten them with a small amount of processing medium.
Transfer the digested solutions to the 70 μm cell strainer.
Rince the cell strainer with 2 mL of processing medium.
Transfer the flow-through to the 40 μm cell strainer.
Rince the cell strainer with the remaining processing medium.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 250 × g for 8 min at 8°C.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cell pellet with 4 mL of RBC lysis buffer, incubate for 3 min at 20°C, and add 20 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge at 250 × g for 8 min at 8°C and discard the supernatant (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Resuspend the cell pellet in sorting buffer for cell isolation or in PBS for intratracheal transplantation.
Note: Isolate murine AT2 cells by FACS for transplantation. Cancer cells can be transplanted without further cell selection.
Isolation of murine AT2 cells by FACS
Timing: 1 h
This part details the isolation of murine AT2 cells using FACS.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] The following steps are designed for acquisition on a BD FACS Aria III.
Prepare cell suspension for AT2 cell isolation by FACS.
Resuspend cells in sorting buffer (4–6 × 106 cells/mL of live cells).
Transfer 2.5 mL of cell suspension into a 5 mL round-bottom tube.
Centrifuge at 250 × g for 5 min at 8°C.

Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend cells in 100 μL of the antibody mix.
Incubate for 20 min at 4°C in the dark.
Add 1 mL of sorting buffer and centrifuge at 250 × g for 5 min at 8°C.
Resuspend cells in 350 μL of sorting buffer.
Note: Keep the tube on ice in the dark until sorting.
Isolate AT2 cells by FACS.
Add 7 μL of 7-AAD and incubate for 5 min on ice in the dark.
Briefly vortex the tube and pass samples through a cell strainer before sorting. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Start running the samples. After gating cells in the plot of forward scatter (FSC)-area versus side scatter (SSC)-area plot, identify dead cells as 7-AAD positive cells followed by doublet exclusion in the plots of FSC-height vs. FSC-width and SSC-height vs. SSC-width.
Identify AT2 cells as EpCAMmedMHCII+ cells among CD45−CD31− cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2451-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Gating strategy for alveolar type 2 cell isolation
After excluding debris, dead cells, and doublets, AT2 cells are identified as the EpCAMmedMHCII+ population among CD45−CD31−cells.
Sort AT2 cells into a 15 mL conical tube containing 11 mL of processing medium.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 10 min at 8°C and resuspend cells in PBS.
Count the total cell number and adjust it to the appropriate cell number for AT2 cell transplantation (usually 400,000 cells/100 μL).
Note: An expected number of sorted AT2 cells from 8–10-week-old mice is approximately 800,000 cells/lung.
Intratracheal transplantation
Timing: 3 min/mouse
This part details how to administer cell suspension into the BLM model by oropharyngeal aspiration.
Anesthetize BLM model mice with 3% isoflurane for 2 min. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Hung the mouse with its front teeth on a rubber band at a 45-degree angle.

Apply 100 μL of single cell suspension (AT2 cells or lung cancer cells) for oropharyngeal aspiration (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Note: The procedure is the same as oropharyngeal aspiration of BLM.
Note: The application volume depends on the ethical approval of the animal protocol in each institution. Adjust the cell concentration so as to follow the approval.
Critical: When anesthetizing mice, monitor the respiratory pattern of the mice carefully. The thoracic movement of the mice becomes shallow very acutely after starting the anesthesia.
